{{Orphan|date=August 2016}}
The '''National Clean Energy Business Plan Competition''' (NCEBPC) is a [[U.S. Department of Energy]] (DOE) program in six regions in the [[United States]] in [[Architectural technology|Building Technologies]], [[Advanced Manufacturing]], [[Transport|Vehicle Technologies]], [[Federal Energy Management Program]], [[Weatherization|Weatherization and Intergovernmental]], [[biomass|Biomass Program]], [[Geothermal|Geothermal Technologies]], [[Fuel Cells|Fuel Cells Technologies]], [[Solar Energy|Solar Energy Technologies]] and [[Wind Energy|Wind]] and [[Hydropower|Hydropower Technologies]], as recognized by the [[Office of Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy]].<ref>[http://techportal.eere.energy.gov/commercialization/natlbizplan.html Website of NCEBPC] at [[U.S. Department of Energy]]</ref>
==Background== It was launched in 2011, with [[Obama Administration]]'s [[American Jobs Act|Startup America Initiative]], a [[White House]] campaign to inspire and promote [[entrepreneurship]]. Each regional winner receives DOE prize money and a chance to compete for a National Grand Prize at a competition held in [[Washington, D.C.]].
In the competition, student ventures the top [[Higher education in the United States|U.S. universities]] form a complete [[business plan]] that [[Commercialization|commercializes a technology]] developed at their school or one of the [[United States Department of Energy national laboratories|National Labs]]. Venture teams are rank the plans on their clean energy impact, solution creativity, execution and [[Venture capital financing|financial]] [[Strategic planning|strategy]], [[market research|market]] and customer knowledge, and team composition, chemistry and commitment.
===Regions=== *MIT Clean Energy Prize at [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] *First Look West at [[Caltech]] *Cleantech New Venture Challenge at [[Colorado University]] *Clean Energy Student Challenge at [http://cleanenergytrust.org/ Clean Energy Trust] *DOE Clean Energy Prize - Rice Business Plan Competition at [[Rice University]] *ACC Clean Energy Challenge at [[University of Maryland]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://blogs.scientificamerican.com/plugged-in/hyliion-takes-top-prize-at-national-clean-energy-business-plan-competition/ NCEBPC] at ''[[Scientific American]]'' *[http://www.clustermapping.us/blog/2014/05/30/us-department-energy-national-clean-energy-business-plan-competition-cleantech-forum NCEBPC] at [http://www.clustermapping.us/ U.S. Cluster Mapping], [[Harvard Business School]]
[[Category:Renewable energy]] [[Category:Renewable energy policy]] [[Category:Renewable energy in the United States]]

{{Infobox winter storm |name=November 2009 nor'easter ("Nor'Ida") |image location=Nor'easter Ida on November 12, 2009.jpg |image name=Satellite image of the storm on November 12 |stormtype=[[Nor'easter]] |date formed=November 11, 2009 |date dissipated=November 17, 2009 |maximum rain={{convert|18|in|mm|abbr=on}} in [[Hampton, Virginia]] |pressure=992 [[Bar (unit)|mbar]] ([[Pascal (unit)|hPa]]; 29.29 [[Inches of Mercury|inHg]]) |total damages (USD)=$300 million (2009 USD) |total fatalities=6 direct |areas affected=[[Mid-Atlantic States]] and [[New England]] }} The '''November 2009 nor'easter''' (also referred to as '''"Nor'Ida"''') was a powerful autumn [[nor'easter]] that caused widespread damage throughout the east coast of the United States. This [[extratropical cyclone]] formed in relation to [[Hurricane Ida (2009)|Hurricane Ida's]] mid-level circulation across southeastern Georgia and moved east-northeast offshore North Carolina before slowly dropping south and southeast over the succeeding several days.
==Synoptic history== [[File:Ida 2009 track.png|thumb|left|Track map of Hurricane Ida]] The origins of the nor'easter originated from with the remnants of Hurricane Ida, a storm that formed on November 4 over the southern Caribbean Sea.<ref name="TCR"/> After tracking through Nicaragua as a [[SSHS#Category 1|Category 1 hurricane]], the system attained [[SSHS#Category 2|Category 2]] status over the [[Yucatán Channel]]. Once in the [[Gulf of Mexico]], the combination of increasing [[wind shear]] and cooler waters caused Ida to weaken. The system eventually moved over the southeastern United States on November 10 before transitioning into an [[extratropical cyclone]]. Ida eventually dissipated over the [[Florida Panhandle]].<ref name="TCR"/> However, Ida's mid-level circulation led to the formation of a new low over southeastern [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], which eventually moved off the coast of [[North Carolina]].<ref name="NOAArpt">{{cite web|author1=Kathleen Egan |author2=Laurita Brown |author3=Karen Earwaker |author4=Colleen Fanelli |author5=Adam Grodsky |author6=Aijun Zhang |publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|date=May 2010|accessdate=December 22, 2010|title=Effects of the November 2009 Nor'easter on Water Levels|url=http://tidesandcurrents.noaa.gov/publications/tech_rpt_56.pdf|format=[[PDF]]}}</ref> This new low quickly intensified and became a powerful [[nor'easter]] that caused substantial damage throughout the [[Mid-Atlantic States]].<ref name="TCR"/> Due to the rapid succession of these systems, United States media referred to the nor'easter as "Nor'Ida".<ref name="USGS1">{{cite web|author1=St. Petersburg Coastal |author2=Marine Science Center |lastauthoramp=yes |publisher=United States Geological Survey|date=March 26, 2010|accessdate=December 23, 2010|title=Nor'Ida|url=http://coastal.er.usgs.gov/hurricanes/norida/}}</ref> By November 12, the system attained a minimum pressure of 992 mbar (hPa; 29.29 inHg) along with winds of 65 mph (100 km/h).<ref name="NASAIda"/> In combination with a large [[High pressure area|area of high pressure]], a long stretch of easterly, onshore winds impacted areas from [[Virginia]] to southern [[New England]].<ref name="PA34">{{cite web|author=Paul J. Kocin|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|date=November 12, 2009|accessdate=December 22, 2010|title=Public Advisory 34 for Remnants of Ida|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/2009/IDA/IDA_34.html}}</ref> Tracking parallel to the North Carolina coastline, the system eventually moved onshore near [[Cape Hatteras, North Carolina|Cape Hatteras]] by November 13. Due to the high pressure system situated over [[Vermont]], the low turned southeastward, bringing its center back over water. Gradual weakening took place during this period, though heavy rains continued to fall across much of the [[Chesapeake Bay]] area. On November 14, a brief secondary low developed off the coast of Delaware.<ref name="NOAArpt"/> Continuing to weaken, the cyclone resumed a northward track after the high weakened and persisted through November 17, by which time it had moved over [[Atlantic Canada]].<ref name="HPCIda"/>
==Preparations== [[File:Ida 2009 rainfall.png|thumb|right|300px|Rainfall from Hurricane Ida and the subsequent nor'easter in the United States]] As the remnants of Ida began to weaken within the developing nor'easter on November 11, [[flood warning]]s were already in force from [[Alabama]] to [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] and [[flood watch|watches]] extended northward into the [[Mid-Atlantic states]]. Coastal flood watches and high wind warnings were also in effect from North Carolina to [[Delaware]].<ref name="PA32">{{cite web|author=Michael T. Eckert|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|date=November 12, 2009|accessdate=December 22, 2010|title=Public Advisory Number 32 for Remnants of Ida|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/2009/IDA/IDA_32.html}}</ref> Flood warnings were later expanded into South Carolina and coastal advisories were extended to New Jersey and [[Long Island, New York|Long Island]].<ref name="PA33">{{cite web|author1=Michael T. Eckert |author2=Paul A. Ziegenfelder |lastauthoramp=yes |publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|date=November 12, 2009|accessdate=December 22, 2010|title=Public Advisory 33 for Remnants of Ida|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/2009/IDA/IDA_33.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=David M. Roth|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|date=November 12, 2009|accessdate=December 23, 2010|title=Public Advisory 35 for Remnants of Ida|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/2009/IDA/IDA_35.html}}</ref> Gale warnings continued to grow in coverage, encompassing areas from North Carolina to New Jersey by the afternoon of November 12.<ref>{{cite web|author= Paul A. Ziegenfelder|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|date=November 12, 2009|accessdate=December 23, 2010|title=Public Advisory 36 for Remnants of Ida|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/2009/IDA/IDA_36.html}}</ref> By November 13, the watches and warnings gradually began to be discontinued as the low moved offshore.<ref>{{cite web|author=Marybeth Gerhardt|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|date=November 13, 2010|accessdate=December 23, 2010|title=Public Advisory 38 on Remnants of Ida|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/2009/IDA/IDA_38.html}}</ref> Although the [[Hydrometeorological Prediction Center]] issued their final advisory on the system later on November 13, flood advisories remained in effect due to residual impacts from the cyclone.<ref>{{cite web|author=David M. Roth|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|date=November 13, 2009|accessdate=December 23, 2010|title=Public Advisory 39 on Remnants of Ida (Final)|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/2009/IDA/IDA_39.html}}</ref>
==Impact==
===Storm surge=== Due to the location of the storm, south east of the Chesapeake Bay, persistent onshore flows brought elevated water levels to some areas for up to four days. This also brought a [[storm surge]] to much of the region and in some cases, these surges reached record levels set by [[Hurricane Isabel]] in 2003.<ref name="NOAArpt"/> In [[Norfolk, Virginia]], a maximum storm surge of {{convert|7.74|ft|m|abbr=on}} was measured on November 13.<ref name="NWSrpt1"/> Five coastal measuring stations recorded record-high water levels during the event and three were within {{convert|0.5|ft|m|abbr=on}}. Despite the nor'easter not being nearly as intense as Hurricane Isabel, water levels rivaled that of the hurricane because of persistent onshore flows, elevating water levels for several days.<ref name="NOAArpt"/>
===Southeastern states=== [[File:Nor'Ida Virginia damage.jpg|thumb|left|300px|Before and after images of a beach in Virginia depicting the severity of beach erosion]] Along the east coast of the United States, a [[nor'easter]] spawned by the remnants of Ida resulted in widespread damage along coastal areas.<ref name="TCR">{{cite web|author1=Lixion A. Avila |author2=John Cangialosi |lastauthoramp=yes |publisher=National Hurricane Center|date=January 14, 2010|accessdate=February 27, 2010|title=Hurricane Ida Tropical Cyclone Report|url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL112009_Ida}}|format=[[PDF]]}}</ref> Minor damage was reported in [[South Carolina]] as winds up to 45 mph (75 km/h) and heavy rains, amounting to {{convert|3|to|5|in|mm|abbr=on}} in most of the state, impacted the region. One person was killed after his vehicle collided with a downed tree in.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2010|accessdate=February 27, 2010|title=South Carolina Event Report: Strong Wind|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~788075}}</ref> Flash flooding took place in some areas due to the heavy rains and previously saturated grounds.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2010|accessdate=December 23, 2010|title=South Carolina Event Report: Flash Flood|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~788076}}</ref> In [[North Carolina]] strong winds downed several trees loosened in saturated soil. In [[Rockingham County, North Carolina|Rockingham County]], one person was killed after being struck by a branch while driving.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2010|accessdate=February 27, 2010|title=North Carolina Event Report: Strong Winds|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~788001}}</ref> In the [[Outer Banks]], four homes were destroyed and over 500 others were damaged by the system, leaving at least $5.8 million in losses.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2010|accessdate=February 27, 2010|title=North Carolina Event Report: Coastal Flood|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~788167}}</ref>
===Mid-Atlantic and Northeast=== Along the [[Delmarva Peninsula]], waves up to {{convert|10|ft|m|abbr=on}} caused some coastal damage and high winds left roughly 13,000 without power. In [[Delaware]] alone, damage was estimated at $45 million.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2010|accessdate=February 27, 2010|title=Delaware Event Report: Coastal Flood|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~788480}}</ref> The most severe damage took place in New Jersey where coastal losses were estimated to be at least $180 million. Extensive sand loss was reported at numerous beaches, including 7 million cubic yards in [[Ocean City, New Jersey|Ocean City]] alone.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2010|accessdate=February 27, 2010|title=New Jersey Event Report: High Winds|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~788465}}</ref> In New York, one person drowned after being caught in rough seas off Rockaway Beach.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2010|accessdate=February 27, 2010|title=New York Event Report: High Surf|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~788306}}</ref> Total beach losses in the state reached $8.2 million.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2010|accessdate=February 27, 2010|title=New York Event Report: High Surf|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~788509}}</ref> Further north, the remnants of the cyclone brought heavy rains to portions of [[New England]], resulting in flash flooding. In [[Maine]], the highest rainfall total was recorded in [[Wells, Maine|Wells]] at {{convert|6.3|in|mm|abbr=on}}. In [[Cumberland County, Maine|Cumberland County]], one river rose {{convert|3.76|ft|m|abbr=on}} above flood-stage, inundating nearby areas.<ref name="NCDCME1">{{cite web|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2010|accessdate=February 27, 2010|title=Maine Event Report: Flood|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~788268}}</ref>
===Virginia=== Widespread coastal damage and major flooding took place in Virginia as rainfall exceeding {{convert|7|in|mm|abbr=on}} fell in many places and large waves affected beaches.<ref name="TCR"/><ref name="HPCIda">{{cite web|author=David M. Roth|publisher=Hydrometeorological Prediction Center|year=2010|accessdate=February 27, 2010|title=Hurricane Ida - November 10–14, 2009|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/ida2009.html}}</ref> A maximum rainfall of {{convert|18|in|mm|abbr=on}} fell in [[Hampton, Virginia|Hampton]] during the storm.<ref name="HPCIda"/> In some areas, roads were closed multiple times due to flooding. Minor damage was also reported as a few homes were inundated with up to {{convert|1|ft|m|abbr=on}} of water. Some areas reported a storm surge comparable to that of Hurricanes [[Hurricane Gloria|Gloria]] in [[1985 Atlantic hurricane season|1985]] and [[Hurricane Isabel|Isabel]] in [[2003 Atlantic hurricane season|2003]].<ref>{{cite web|publisher=National Climatic Data Center|year=2010|accessdate=February 27, 2010|title=Virginia Event Report: Coastal Flood|url=http://www4.ncdc.noaa.gov/cgi-win/wwcgi.dll?wwevent~ShowEvent~788468}}</ref> Damage from the storm in Virginia was estimated to be at least $38.8 million, of which $25 million was in [[Norfolk, Virginia|Norfolk]] alone.<ref name="NASAIda">{{cite web|publisher=National Aeronautics and Space Administration|date=December 4, 2009|accessdate=February 27, 2010|title=Hurricane Season 2009: Ida the Coastal Low|url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/hurricanes/archives/2009/h2009_Ida.html}}</ref> According to the [[National Weather Service]], {{convert|7.4|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rain fell in Norfolk between November 11 and 13, nearly three times the monthly average for November; in those three days alone, the total rainfall surpassed the monthly record of {{convert|7.02|in|mm|abbr=on}} set in 1951. Hurricane-force winds also affected the state, with a peak gust of {{convert|75|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} occurring in [[Oceana, Virginia|Oceana]].<ref name="NWSrpt1">{{cite web|author=National Weather Service|publisher=National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|date=November 2010|accessdate=October 14, 2010|title=November 11-13th, 2009 Nor'easter|url=http://www.erh.noaa.gov/er/akq/wx_events/other/November%2011-13th%20Noreaster.pdf|format=[[PDF]]}}</ref>
==Aftermath== Following the widespread flooding caused by the storm, a [[Disaster area|major disaster declaration]] was signed by [[Barack Obama|President Barack Obama]] on December 9 to provide residents in Virginia with federal assistance. According to the [[Federal Emergency Management Agency]] (FEMA), the cost of federal public assistance in the state would reach $11,227,376.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Federal Emergency Management Agency|date=December 9, 2009|accessdate=December 22, 2010|title=Virginia Severe Storms and Flooding Associated with Tropical Depression Ida and a Nor’easter|url=http://www.fema.gov/pdf/news/pda/1862.pdf|format=[[PDF]]}}</ref>
==See also== *[[October 2009 North American storm complex]]: formed from the remnant circulation associated with [[Typhoon Melor (2009)|Typhoon Melor]] in a similar manner *[[Winter storms of 2009-2010]] *[[November 2006 nor'easter]] *[[2009 Atlantic hurricane season]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *{{NHC TCR url|id=AL112009_Ida|title=The National Hurricane Center's Tropical Cyclone Report on Hurricane Ida}} *[http://coastal.er.usgs.gov/hurricanes/norida/post-storm-photos/20091204_NorIda.kmz Oblique aerial photography and video of post-storm damage from the nor'easter] (KMZ)
{{DEFAULTSORT:November 2009 Mid-Atlantic Nor'easter}} [[Category:2009 meteorology]] [[Category:Nor'easters]] [[Category:2009 natural disasters]]

{{Infobox person | name = Philip H. Diehl. | image = Philip Diehl.jpg | caption = | birth_date ={{birth date|1847|01|29}}. | birth_place =[[Flörsheim-Dalsheim|Dalsheim]], [[Germany]] | death_date ={{death date and age|1913|04|07|1847|01|29}} | death_place =[[Elizabeth, New Jersey]], [[United States|U.S.]] | occupation = [[Engineer]], [[inventor]] | spouse = Emilie Loos | religion = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Philip H. Diehl''' (January 29, 1847 – April 7, 1913) was a [[Germany|German]]-[[United States|American]] mechanical [[engineer]] and [[inventor]] who held several U.S. [[patent]]s, including [[light bulb|electric incandescent lamp]]s, [[electric motor]]s for [[sewing machine]]s and other uses, and [[ceiling fan]]s. Diehl was a contemporary of [[Thomas Edison]] and his inventions caused Edison to reduce the price of his incandescent bulb.
He occasionally spelled his first name 'Phillip'.<ref>Diehl spelled and signed his first name 'Phillip' in his US patent 208838, awarded 8 October 1878</ref>
==Early life== Philip H. Diehl was born in [[Flörsheim-Dalsheim|Dalsheim]], [[Germany]].<ref name="EDJ1929">"Diehl's Lamp Hit Edison Monopoly," Elizabeth Daily Journal, Friday Evening, October 25, 1929</ref>
In July 1868, he immigrated to [[New York City]] where he worked in several machine shops before finding work as an apprentice with the [[Singer Manufacturing Company]]. In 1870 or 1871 he was transferred to [[Chicago, Illinois]] and worked at [[Remington Products|Remington Machine Company]] until 1875. He lost all of his possessions in the [[Great Chicago Fire]] of 1871. In 1873, Diehl married Emilie Loos in Chicago.<ref name="EDJ1929"/>
In 1875, Diehl moved to [[Elizabeth, New Jersey]] and took charge of experimental work improving sewing machines at the Singer plant. His daughter, Clara Elvira, was born April 2, 1876.<ref name="EDJ1929"/>
==Inventions== While working at Singer in Elizabeth, Diehl experimented at work and at his home. This resulted in several inventions.
===Electric light=== Working in the basement of his home on Orchard Street in Elizabeth, New Jersey, Diehl invented a lamp that was different from [[Thomas Edison]]'s incandescent electric lamp, which was patented in 1879. Diehl's lamp had no lead-in wires. In 1882 Diehl obtained the first patent on this induction incandescent lamp. The base of the lamp contained a wire coil that coupled with a primary coil in the lamp socket, causing current to flow through the lamp without the need for lead-in wires. Two additional patents were granted in 1883, followed by patents for electrical lighting systems in 1885 and 1886.<ref name="EDJ1929"/><ref name="EDISONIAN">{{cite web |url=http://www.edisonian.com/p004b006.htm |title=Diehl lamp |accessdate=2007-12-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/19991004060012/http://www.edisonian.com/p004b006.htm |archivedate=1999-10-04 |df= }}</ref>
Following is a partial list of lamp or lighting related patents issued to Philip Diehl:<ref name="EDJ1929"/> *U.S. No. 255,497, Incandescent Electric Lamp, March 28, 1882 *U.S. No. 272,125, Electric Incandescent Lamp, February 13, 1883 *U.S. No. 276,571, Incandescent Electric Lamp, May 1, 1883 *U.S. No. 314,567, Electric Arc Lamp, March 31, 1885 *U.S. No. 350,482, Electric Lighting System, October 12, 1886
Diehl erected the city's first arc light in front of the Corey Building in Elizabeth, which still stands at 109 Broad Street.<ref name="EDJ1929"/>
Diehl's invention of the induction lamp was used by [[George Westinghouse]] to force royalty concessions from Thomas Edison. The Westinghouse Company bought Diehl's patent rights for $25,000. Although Diehl's lamp could not be made and sold at a price to compete with the Edison lamp, the Westinghouse Company used the Diehl bulb to force the holders of the Edison patent to charge a more reasonable rate for the use of the Edison patent rights.<ref name="EDJ1929"/>
===Sewing machine=== Together with Lebbeus B. Miller, Diehl invented and patented the "oscillating shuttle" [[bobbin drivers|bobbin driver]] designed and a sewing machine build around it. {{main|Bobbin drivers}}
===Electric engines=== Diehl's work at Singer to improve the sewing machine led to developments in electric motors, first to power sewing machines and later for other uses as well. In 1884 at the [[Franklin Institute]] in [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]] he demonstrated a [[dynamo]], modeled after his smaller motor, which generated a current for arc lamps, sewing machine motors and incandescent lamps, all covered by his patents. The judicial committee at the exhibition judged it to be one of the best dynamos exhibited.<ref name="UNION">"Philip Diehl", History of Union County, New Jersey, Vol 2, A. Van Doren Honeyman, 1923, pp 117-118.</ref>
===Ceiling fan=== The fan was invented in 1882 by [[Schuyler Wheeler|Schuyler Skaats Wheeler]]. A few years later, Philip Diehl mounted a fan [[blade]] on a [[sewing machine]] [[Electric motor|motor]] and attached it to the ceiling, inventing the [[ceiling fan]], which he patented in 1887. Later, he added a [[light fixture]] to the ceiling fan. Later in 1904,Diehl and Co. added a split-ball joint, allowing it to be redirected; three years later, this developed into the first [[oscillating]] [[Fan (mechanical)|fan]].<ref name="NEWSFINDER">{{cite web |url=http://www.newsfinder.org/site/more/ceiling_fans/ |title=NEWSFINDER Ceiling Fans |accessdate=2008-01-01}}</ref>
==Death== Philip Diehl died on April 7, 1913 in [[Elizabeth, New Jersey]].<ref name="EDJ1929"/><ref>Obituary Notes, Philip H. Diehl, The New York Times, Tuesday, April 8, 1913, page 13, column 6.</ref>
==Honors== In 1889 the American Institute of New York awarded Philip Diehl a bronze medal, which bears the inscription ''The Medal of Merit, awarded to Philip Diehl for Electric Fans and Dynamos, 1889.''<ref name="UNION"/>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[https://archive.is/20121220005058/http://home.frognet.net/~ejcov/diehl.html Story of Philip Diehl] (contains online references to many of the sources in the References section)
{{DEFAULTSORT:Diehl, Philip}} [[Category:1847 births]] [[Category:1913 deaths]] [[Category:People from Rhenish Hesse]] [[Category:American inventors]] [[Category:German inventors]] [[Category:German emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:People associated with electricity]] [[Category:People from Elizabeth, New Jersey]] [[Category:People from Alzey-Worms]]

revision.text:
A '''Renewable Energy Service Company (RESCO)''' is an ESCO [[Energy service company]] which provides energy to the consumers from renewable energy sources, usually [[Photovoltaics|solar photovoltaics]], [[wind power]] or [[micro hydro]].
RESCOs include [[Investor-owned utility|investor owned]], [[Public ownership|publicly owned]], [[cooperatives]], and [[community organisation]]s.
== Main characteristics == The main characteristics of a RESCO are: * The household serviced does not own the generation equipment, which is owned by an external organisation such as a Government agency or the RESCO; * The user does not carry out maintenance, all maintenance and repair service is provided by the RESCO; * The user pays a service charge that covers the capital repayment requirement and the cost of providing for maintenance and repairs.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fdoe.gov.fj/ReportsRenewableEnergy/Charter%20for%20Renewable%20Energy%20Based%20Rural%20Electrification%20Nov%202002.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-08-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071110201137/http://www.fdoe.gov.fj/ReportsRenewableEnergy/Charter%20for%20Renewable%20Energy%20Based%20Rural%20Electrification%20Nov%202002.pdf |archivedate=2007-11-10 |df= }}</ref>
The concept is much like that of a conventional [[electric utility]] in that the generation equipment is not owned by the user and the electricity that is generated is made available to the customer for a fee. The fee charged to the user includes any required capital replacement cost and all operating, maintenance and repair costs plus a profit for the operating organisation.
There are two significant differences between the conventional utility approach and that of the RESCO. For a RESCO: * Generation may be distributed among many households instead of being centralised at a [[power station]]; * Many organisations regulated by the government may provide services independently of each other.
== RESCOs & rural electrification == RESCOs have been very successful in the expansion of [[rural electrification]] projects worldwide because: * Low income rural households receive electricity without having to invest in renewable energy equipment, something that they would not normally be able to afford due to the high initial cost. * Equipment is properly maintained and components replaced by the RESCO, making sure that the service is not interrupted, * Equipment is owned by an organization that directly or indirectly represents the users (beneficiaries of the funding).
As a result of all this, donors are prepared to contribute with funding to the RESCO concept because it makes their aid (1) effective, (2) sustainable and (3) accountable.<ref>Akura, Terubentau & Torra Griso, Marc "Solar Home Systems Technical & Management Model in Kiribati". SOPAC Regional Energy Meeting , Tonga, 20 – 24 April 2009 </ref>
== RESCOs in the Pacific == Pacific Governments have provided rural electrification to remote locations by means of four main institutional set-ups, which are: * Engaging the power utility in carrying out the rural electrification. This is the approach followed in [[Marshall Islands]] by the Marshall Electric Company (MEC) or in the Federated States of Micronesia by the Yap State Public Service Corporation (YSPSC) and the Chuuk Power Utility Corporation (CPUC). * Setting up a different entity for the rural electrification (RESCO), but still centralising much of the decision making process in Government officials through the nomination of a board of directors. This is the strategy applied in [[Kiribati]], with the Kiribati Solar Energy Company Ltd (KSEC). * Decentralising operation and maintenance by engaging the private sector, while keeping the ownership of the equipment in the hands of a government department. This is the solution followed in [[Fiji]] with the RESCO charter and in [[Pohnpei]] State ([[Federated States of Micronesia]]). * Decentralising operation and maintenance by engaging the users, and transferring ownership of the equipment to the organisation that represents them. This was the solution followed in [[Tonga]] though the Ha'apai District Solar Electricity Committee before deciding to engage the power utility in providing the service.

revision.text:
Under its commitment to the [[EU Renewable Energy Directive 2009/28/EC|EU renewable energy directive]] of 2009, France has a target of producing 23% of its total energy needs from renewable energy by 2020. This figure breaks down to renewable energy providing 33% of energy used in the heating and cooling sector, 27% of the electricity sector and 10.5% in the transport sector. By the end of 2014, 14.3% of France's total energy requirements came from renewable energy, a rise from 9.6% in 2005.{{Cite web|url = https://ec.europa.eu/energy/en/topics/renewable-energy/national-action-plans|title = National action plan for the promotion of renewable energies 2009-2020 In accordance with Article 4 of European Union Directive 2009/28/EC|last =|first =|date =|website =|publisher =|access-date =}} The outlook for renewable electricity in France received a boost following the publication in October 2016 of the "Programmation pluriannuelle de l'énergie", showing a commitment to re-balancing the electricity mix towards renewables. According to the report, renewable electricity capacity is planned to grow from 41 GW in 2014 to between 71 and 78 GW by 2023.{{Cite web|url=http://www.developpement-durable.gouv.fr/Programmation-pluriannuelle-de-l,48569.html|title=Ministre de l'Environnement, de l'Énergie et de la Mer, Programmation pluriannuelle de l'énergie, 27 October 2016.|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}} Historically the electricity sector in France has been dominated by the country's longstanding commitment to [[nuclear power]]. However, the report emphasizes that by 2025 more than half of [[Nuclear power in France|France's nuclear power capacity]] will come from stations that will be 40 years or older, and subject to closure or refurbishment to extend their operation. Thus, there is a need to look to other sources, including renewables, to meet the expected generating-capacity shortfall.{{Cite web|url = http://www.developpement-durable.gouv.fr/Programmation-pluriannuelle-de-l,48569.html|title = Ministre de l'Environnement, de l'Énergie et de la Mer, Programmation pluriannuelle de l'énergie, 27 October 2016, pg 110.|last =|first =|date =|website =|publisher =|access-date =}} A key component of France's renewable target is the commitment to greatly increase energy efficiency, particularly for buildings and thermal insulation. Heat wastage is targeted to be reduced by 38% by 2020. The renewable targets are also intended to stimulate new trades and changes to existing trades to enable green growth. The PPE plan targets the reduction of the consumption of primary fossil energy by 22% in 2023 from 2012 levels (reference scenario) or a fallback scenario of an 11% reduction under less-favorable conditions (variant scenario).{{Cite web|url = http://www.developpement-durable.gouv.fr/Programmation-pluriannuelle-de-l,48569.html|title = Ministre de l'Environnement, de l'Énergie et de la Mer, Programmation pluriannuelle de l'énergie, 27 October 2016, p15.|last =|first =|date =|website =|publisher =|access-date =}} In terms of the reduction in primary consumption, petroleum products are targeted to fall by 23% between 2012 and 2023 (reference scenario) or 9.5% (variant scenario), gas by 16% (9% variant scenario) and coal by 37% (30% variant scenario). In the transport sector, France has a range of initiatives designed to promote renewable energy use and increase efficiency. These include changing transport behavior, such as a target of 10% of [[Telecommuting|tele-worked]] days by 2030 to reduce consumption.{{Cite web|url = http://www.developpement-durable.gouv.fr/Programmation-pluriannuelle-de-l,48569.html|title = Ministre de l'Environnement, de l'Énergie et de la Mer, Programmation pluriannuelle de l'énergie, 27 October 2016, p33.|last =|first =|date =|website =|publisher =|access-date =}} By 2023, the country aims to have a fleet of 2.4 million rechargeable electric and [[hybrid vehicle]]s and for 3% of heavy-duty applications to use [[natural gas vehicle]]s (NGVs). [[Biofuel]]s blended with petrol are set for 1.8% in 2018 and 3.4% in 2023, and for diesel 1% in 2018 and 2.3% in 2023. By 2030, non-road freight transport is targeted to reach 20% of all goods. Initiatives to increase walking and cycling are also being undertaken. [[Carpool|Car pooling]] and digital services will be promoted to increase occupancy rates to between 1.8 and 2 people by 2030. The country is also pursuing research and development of [[Vehicular automation|autonomous vehicles]], particularly in public transport. == Renewable electricity overview and targets == {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:right" |+Renewable electricity planned capacity by source 2014–2023 (MW) !rowspan="2"| !rowspan="2"|2014 !rowspan="2"|2018 !colspan="2"|2023 |- !low scenario !high scenario |- | align="left" | [[Wind power in France#Onshore wind power|Onshore wind]] | 9,300 | 15,000 | 21,800 | 26,000 |- | align="left" | [[Wind power in France#Offshore wind power|Offshore wind]] | | 500 | colspan="2" style="text-align: center;" |3,000an additional 500 to 6,000 to be deployed, following consultations in the proposed zones, the outcome and results of the first projects and on the basis of costs. |- | align="left" | Marine energy
[[Wind power in France#Floating turbine test sites|floating wind turbines]], underwater turbines etc. | | | colspan="2" style="text-align: center;" |100an additional 200 to 2,000 capacity deployed, depending on the outcome of the trial projects and according to costs |- | align="left" | [[Solar power in France|Solar {{abbr|PV|photovoltaic}}]] | 5,300 | 10,200 | 18,200 | 20,200 |- | align="left" | [[Renewable energy in France#Hydroelectric power|Hydroelectric]] | 25,300 | 25,300 | 25,800 | 26,050 |- | align="left" | Bio energy | 357 | 540 | 790 | 1,040 |- | align="left" | Methanisation | 85 | 137 | 237 | 300 |- | align="left" | Geothermal power | | 8 | colspan="2" style="text-align: center;" | 53 |- | align="left" | Waste
biogas from landfill and treatment works | ~1200 | ~1350 | colspan="2" style="text-align: center;" |~1500 |- | align="left" | '''Total''' | '''41,000''' | '''52,000''' | '''71,000''' | '''78,000''' |} During 2016 renewable electricity accounted for 19.6% of France's total domestic power consumption, of which 12.2% was provided by hydroelectricity, 4.3% by wind power, 1.7% by solar power and 1.4% by bio energy.{{Cite web|url=http://www.rte-france.com/sites/default/files/panorama_enr20161231.pdf|title=Panorama de l'électricité renouvelable en 2016|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}} According to the report "Programmation pluriannuelle de l'énergie" renewable electricity capacity is targeted to grow from 41 GW capacity in 2014 to 52 GW by 2018 and between 71 and 78 GW by 2023. The target for 2023 includes a high and low scenario to take into account external factors such as cost and consultations that may affect future deployment. The sources that are planned to grow fastest are wind and solar photovoltaic (PV) power; 500 MW of offshore wind power is expected to be grid-connected by 2018. Onshore wind power is set to grow from around 9 GW in 2014 to between approximately 22 and 26 GW by 2023. Offshore wind power is targeted to grow from zero capacity in 2014 to between 3.5 GW and 9 GW by 2023, and up to an additional 2 GW of marine energy. Solar PV power is projected to grow from around 5.3 GW in 2014 to between 18.2 GW and 20.2 GW by 2023. Hydroelectric power is already well developed in France but is targeted to grow 500–750 MW by 2023. == Heating and cooling == {| class="wikitable" |+Final energy consumption by renewable energy technology in the heating and cooling sector ({{abbr|ktoe|kilotonnnes of oil equivalent}}), 2014 {{Cite web|url = https://ec.europa.eu/energy/en/topics/renewable-energy/progress-reports|title = Progress report on the promotion and use of energy from renewable sources, Third report, Ministry of Ecology, Sustainable Development and Energy www.developpement-durable.gouv.fr|last =|first =|date =|website =|publisher =|access-date =}} |colspan="2" |Geothermal (excluding low temperature heat pump applications) |align="right" |126 |- |colspan="2" |Solar |align="right" |159 |- |rowspan="4" |Biomass |solid biomass |align="right" |8,552 |- |biogas |align="right" |109 |- |bioliquids |align="right" |0 |- |Total biomass |align="right" |8,661 |- |rowspan="3" |Heat pump |aerothermal |align="right" |1,533 |- |geothermal & hydrothermal |align="right" |262 |- |Total heat pump |align="right" | 1,794 |- |colspan="2" |'''Total''' |align="right" |'''10,740''' |} Solid biomass accounted for the largest share of renewable energy consumption in the heating and cooling sector at 8,661 ktoe (thousand [[Tonne of oil equivalent|tonnes of oil equivalent]]) in 2014. The next-largest source was provided by [[heat pump]]s at 1,794 ktoe. Heat accounts for about 95% of the energy produced by solid biomass, while the remaining 5% is used to produce electricity.{{Cite web|url=https://www.eurobserv-er.org/solid-biomass-barometer-2016/|title=Solid Biomass Barometer 2016|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}} Energy from wood and wood products accounts for almost all of this production, of which 73% is used to heat family dwellings. During 2015, heat consumption in France (excluding dependencies) from solid biomass amounted to 8,836 ktoe, of which 8,115 ktoe were accounted for by direct use of end user, and 721 ktoe from [[district heating]] sources. District heating networks were supplied during 2015 by both heat-only plants (326 ktoe), and [[Combined Heat And Power|combined heat and power]] plants (395 ktoe). === Thassalia marine geothermal plant === The Thassalia marine geothermal plant is located in the [[Marseille-Fos Port|Grand Port Maritime de Marseille]] and uses marine thermal energy to provide heating and cooling to buildings connected to its network. The first phase of the network was inaugurated in October 2016 and covered {{convert|150,000|m2}}.{{Cite web|url=http://www.renewableenergyworld.com/articles/2016/11/thassalia-france-s-first-marine-geothermal-energy-power-plant-inaugurated.html|title=Renewable Energy World|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170212092244/http://www.renewableenergyworld.com/articles/2016/11/thassalia%2Dfrance%2Ds%2Dfirst%2Dmarine%2Dgeothermal%2Denergy%2Dpower%2Dplant%2Dinaugurated.html|archive-date=2017-02-12|dead-url=yes|access-date=}} The network is planned to be expanded to cover around {{convert|500,000|m2}} of Marseille.{{Cite web|url=http://www.engie.com/en/journalists/press-releases/thassalia-marine-geothermal/|title=ENGIE|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}} The plant pumps seawater from the port of Marseille and extracts the natural heat from the water using large-scale heat pumps to provide heating for the town. The process can be reversed to provide cooling during the hot Mediterranean summer. The project is regarded as a flagship example and it is hoped more will follow, including a much-larger geothermal marine project on the island of [[Réunion|La Réunion]] to supply air conditioning utilizing seawater piped from {{convert|1,100|m}}. == Transport == {{see also|Plug-in electric vehicles in France}} {| class="wikitable" |+Total actual contribution from each renewable energy technology in the transport sector (ktoe, 2014) |rowspan="3" |Bioethanol/bio-ETBE |biofuels per Article 21(2) |align="right" |11 |- |imports |align="right" |56 |- |Total biofuels |align="right" |414 |- |rowspan="3" |Biodiesel |biofuels per Article 21(2) |align="right" |123 |- |imports |align="right" |509 |- |Toal biodiesel |align="right" |2,541 |- |colspan="2" |Hydrogen from renewables |align="right" |0 |- |rowspan="3" |Renewable electricity |for road transport |align="right" |4 |- |for non-road transport |align="right" |247 |- |Total |align="right" |251 |- |colspan="2" |Others (e.g.: biogas, vegetable oils) |align="right" |0 |- |colspan="2" |'''Total''' |align="right" |'''3,340''' |} [[Biodiesel]] provided the largest share of renewable energy in the transport sector at 2,541 ktoe in 2014. In the same year [[Biofuel|bioethanol]] provided the next-largest share at 414 ktoe followed by renewable electricity at 251 ktoe. The stock of light-duty [[plug-in electric vehicles]] registered in France passed the 100,000-unit milestone in October 2016, making the country the second-largest plug-in market in Europe after [[Renewable energy in Norway|Norway]], and fifth worldwide.{{cite news|url=http://www.hybridcars.com/france-becomes-fifth-nation-to-buy-100000-plug-in-vehicles/|title=France Becomes Fifth Nation To Buy 100,000 Plug-in Vehicles|last=Cobb|first=Jeff|date=2016-10-10|work=HybridCars.com|accessdate=2016-10-10}}{{cite news|url=http://www.lefigaro.fr/societes/2016/10/01/20005-20161001ARTFIG00105-plus-de-100000-vehicules-electriques-circulent-aujourd-hui-en-france.php|title=Plus de 100.000 véhicules électriques circulent aujourd'hui en France|last=Foucaud|first=Isabelle|date=2016-10-01|work=[[Le Figaro]]|language=French|trans-title=More than 100,000 electric vehicles currently on the road in France|accessdate=2016-10-10}} ''Environment Minister, Ségolène Royal, said there are more than 100,000 electric vehicles currently on the road in France.'' == Sources == === Hydroelectric power === Database|website=www.energystorageexchange.org|access-date=2017-04-27}} |- |[[Bimont Dam]] |[[Aix-en-Provence]] | | |Water reservoir | |} Hydroelectric power is the largest single source of renewable electricity in France accounting for 12.2% of total domestic power consumption in 2016. According to industry sources in 2014 there were around 2,600 hydroelectric plants of widely varying capacity accounting for 25,400 MW of installed capacity, 436 of these plants were run by EDF ([[Électricité de France]], a French-based utility company largely owned by the state) and accounted for around 19,900 MW of the total capacity.{{Cite news|url=https://www.edf.fr/groupe-edf/espaces-dedies/l-energie-de-a-a-z/tout-sur-l-energie/produire-de-l-electricite/l-hydraulique-en-chiffres|title=L'hydraulique en chiffres|date=2015-07-20|work=EDF France|access-date=2017-04-24|language=fr}} In 2014 France was the world's tenth-largest producer of hydroelectricity, and Europe's second-largest after Norway, producing 69 TWh including [[Pumped-storage hydroelectricity|pumped storage]] production.{{Cite web|url = http://www.iea.org/statistics/|title = IEA, Key World Energy Statistics 2016.|last =|first =|date =|website =|publisher =|access-date =}} In 2016 aggregated hydroelectric plants of greater than 1 MW capacity of the run-of-the-river or poundage type accounted for 10,327 MW, the water reservoir type accounted for 8,231 MW and pumped-storage type 4,965 MW. === Wind power === {{main article|Wind power in France}} {| style="text-align: right" class="wikitable" |+Windpower installed capacity in France{{Cite web|url = http://www.gwec.net/publications/global-wind-report-2/global-wind-report-2015-annual-market-update/|title = GWEC Global Wind Report 2015, p42.|last =|first =|date =|website =|publisher =|access-date =}} ! !2008 !2009 !2010 !2011 !2012 !2013 !2014 !2015 |- | align="left" |Capacity (MW) |3,577 |4,713 |5,977 |6,809 |7,613 |8,558 |9,285 |10,358 |} France has the second-largest wind potential in Europe.{{Cite web|url=http://www.wind-energy-the-facts.org/france.html|title=Wind Energy the Facts|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}} Wind power capacity grew from 3,577 MW in 2008 to 10,358 MW by 2015 as France continues to develop this potential. As of year end 2015 all wind power in France is onshore, total onshore capacity is planned to more than double by 2023. France is committed to developing a large offshore capability, with the first 500 MW of capacity scheduled to come online by 2018.{{Cite web|url=http://www.developpement-durable.gouv.fr/Programmation-pluriannuelle-de-l,48569.html|title=Ministre de l'Environnement, de l'Énergie et de la Mer, Programmation pluriannuelle de l'énergie, 27 October 2016.|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}} By 2023 France could have up to 11 GW of offshore wind and marine energy.{{Cite web|url=http://www.developpement-durable.gouv.fr/Programmation-pluriannuelle-de-l,48569.html|title=Ministre de l'Environnement, de l'Énergie et de la Mer, Programmation pluriannuelle de l'énergie, 27 October 2016.|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}} === Solar PV power === {{main article|Solar power in France}} {| style="text-align: right" class="wikitable" ! !2008 !2009 !2010 !2011 !2012 !2013 !2014 !2015 |- | align="left" |Capacity (MW) |104 |289 |1,197 |2,949 |4,060 |4,673 |5,660 |6,549 |- | align="left" |Generation (GWh) | | |677 |2,400 |4,000 |4,661 |5,500 |6,700 |- | align="left" |Ref |{{cite web|url = http://www.eurobserv-er.org/pdf/baro196.pdf|title = Photovoltaic Barometer - installations 2008 and 2009|website = energies-renouvelables.org|pages = 5|format = PDF|author1 = EUROBSER'VER|accessdate = 1 May 2013|archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6QN2z5NRx?url=http://www.eurobserv-er.org/pdf/baro196.pdf|archivedate = 16 June 2014|deadurl = yes|df = }} |{{cite web|url = http://www.eurobserv-er.org/pdf/baro202.pdf|title = Photovoltaic Barometer - installations 2009 and 2010|website = energies-renouvelables.org|pages = 4|format = PDF|author1 = EUROBSER'VER|accessdate = 1 May 2013|archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6QN2Lx72F?url=http://www.eurobserv-er.org/pdf/baro202.pdf|archivedate = 16 June 2014|deadurl = yes|df = }}{{cite web|url = http://www.eurobserv-er.org/pdf/baro196.pdf|title = Photovoltaic Barometer - installations 2008 and 2009|website = energies-renouvelables.org|pages = 5|format = PDF|author1 = EUROBSER'VER|accessdate = 1 May 2013|archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6QN2z5NRx?url=http://www.eurobserv-er.org/pdf/baro196.pdf|archivedate = 16 June 2014|deadurl = yes|df = }} |{{cite web|url = http://www.eurobserv-er.org/pdf/photovoltaic_2012.pdf|title = Photovoltaic Barometer - installations 2010 and 2011|website = energies-renouvelables.org|pages = 6|format = PDF|author1 = EUROBSER'VER|accessdate = 1 May 2013|archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6QN1OZ1Bt?url=http://www.eurobserv-er.org/pdf/photovoltaic_2012.pdf|archivedate = 16 June 2014|deadurl = yes|df = }}{{cite web|url = http://www.eurobserv-er.org/pdf/baro202.pdf|title = Photovoltaic Barometer - installations 2011 and 2012|website = energies-renouvelables.org|pages = 7|format = PDF|author1 = EUROBSER'VER|accessdate = 1 May 2013|archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6QMzMloMY?url=http://www.energies-renouvelables.org/observ-er/stat_baro/observ/baro-jdp9.pdf|archivedate = 16 June 2014|deadurl = yes|df = }}{{cite web|url = http://www.eurobserv-er.org/pdf/photovoltaic_2012.pdf|title = Photovoltaic Barometer - installations 2010 and 2011|website = energies-renouvelables.org|pages = 6|format = PDF|author1 = EUROBSER'VER|accessdate = 1 May 2013|archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6QN1OZ1Bt?url=http://www.eurobserv-er.org/pdf/photovoltaic_2012.pdf|archivedate = 16 June 2014|deadurl = yes|df = }} |{{cite web|url = http://www.energies-renouvelables.org/observ-er/stat_baro/observ/baro-jdp9.pdf|title = Photovoltaic Barometer - installations 2011 and 2012|website = energies-renouvelables.org|pages = 7|format = PDF|author1 = EUROBSER'VER|accessdate = 1 May 2013|archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6QMzMloMY?url=http://www.energies-renouvelables.org/observ-er/stat_baro/observ/baro-jdp9.pdf|archivedate = 16 June 2014|deadurl = yes|df = }}{{cite web|url = http://www.epia.org/fileadmin/user_upload/Publications/EPIA_Global_Market_Outlook_for_Photovoltaics_2014-2018_-_Medium_Res.pdf|title = Global Market Outlook for Photovoltaics 2014-2018|website = epia.org|publisher = EPIA - European Photovoltaic Industry Association|pages = 24|format = PDF|accessdate = 12 June 2014|archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6QGSvAF7w?url=http://www.epia.org/fileadmin/user_upload/Publications/EPIA_Global_Market_Outlook_for_Photovoltaics_2014-2018_-_Medium_Res.pdf|archivedate = 12 June 2014|deadurl = yes|df = }} |{{cite web|url = http://www.epia.org/fileadmin/user_upload/Publications/EPIA_Global_Market_Outlook_for_Photovoltaics_2014-2018_-_Medium_Res.pdf|title = Global Market Outlook for Photovoltaics 2014-2018|website = www.epia.org|publisher = EPIA - European Photovoltaic Industry Association|pages = 26|format = PDF|accessdate = 12 June 2014|archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6QGSvAF7w?url=http://www.epia.org/fileadmin/user_upload/Publications/EPIA_Global_Market_Outlook_for_Photovoltaics_2014-2018_-_Medium_Res.pdf|archivedate = 12 June 2014|deadurl = yes|df = }} |{{cite web|url = http://www.iea-pvps.org/fileadmin/dam/public/report/technical/PVPS_report_-_A_Snapshot_of_Global_PV_-_1992-2014.pdf|title = Snapshot of Global PV 1992-2014|date = 30 March 2015|website = iea-pvps.org|publisher = International Energy Agency — Photovoltaic Power Systems Programme|archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6XPpb1fai?url=http://www.iea-pvps.org/index.php?id=92&eID=dam_frontend_push&docID=2430|archivedate = 30 March 2015|deadurl = no}}{{cite web|url = http://www.energies-renouvelables.org/observ-er/stat_baro/observ/EurObservER-barojdpv13-Photovoltaic-Barometer-2015-EN.pdf|title = Photovoltaic Barometer - installations 2013 and 2014|date = April 2015|website = energies-renouvelables.org|format = PDF|author1 = EUROBSER'VER|archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6YK1IfR89?url=http://www.energies-renouvelables.org/observ-er/stat_baro/observ/EurObservER-barojdpv13-Photovoltaic-Barometer-2015-EN.pdf|archivedate = 6 May 2015|deadurl = no|df = }} |{{Cite web|url = http://www.developpement-durable.gouv.fr/IMG/pdf/CS732.pdf|title = COMMISSARIAT GENERAL AU DEVELOPPEMENT DURABLE, Chiffres et Statisque no. 732 Feb 2016.|last =|first =|date =|website =|publisher =|access-date =}} |} Solar photovoltaic (PV) power grew from 104 MW capacity in 2008 to 6,549 MW by year end 2015 at which time France had the seventh-largest solar PV installed capacity in the world.{{Cite web|url=http://www.iea-pvps.org/fileadmin/dam/public/report/statistics/IEA-PVPS_-__A_Snapshot_of_Global_PV_-_1992-2015_-_Final.pdf|title=Snapshot of Global Photovoltaic Markets, IEA PVPS p14.|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}} France and is set to undergo significant expansion of its solar power with a target of around 18–20 GW installed capacity by 2023.{{Cite web|url=http://www.developpement-durable.gouv.fr/Programmation-pluriannuelle-de-l,48569.html|title=Ministre de l'Environnement, de l'Énergie et de la Mer, Programmation pluriannuelle de l'énergie, 27 October 2016.|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}} In January 2016, President [[François Hollande]] and the Prime Minister of India, [[Narendra Modi]], laid the foundation stone for the headquarters of the [[Sunshine countries|International Solar Alliance]] (ISA) in Gwalpahari, Gurgaon, India. The ISA will focus on promoting and developing solar energy and solar products for countries lying wholly or partially between the [[Tropic of Cancer]] and the [[Tropic of Capricorn]]. In 2018 EDF had plans to invest up to {{euro}}25 billion in PV power generation, and introduce green electricity tariffs.{{cite news |url=https://www.ft.com/content/9f3ef348-12d0-11e8-8cb6-b9ccc4c4dbbb |title=EDF revenues slip as nuclear pressures bite |author=Cat Rutter Pooley |newspaper=Financial Times |date=16 February 2018 |accessdate=16 February 2018}} === Tidal power === France opened [[Rance Tidal Power Station]], the world's first tidal power station, in 1966. It remained the world's largest tidal station until 2011. Its 24 turbines reach a peak output of 240 MW with an annual output of around 500 GWh. The dam traverses the estuary of the Rance River in [[Brittany]], connecting the tourist towns of Dinard and Saint Malo, providing both a roadbridge and footbridge. In addition the barrage is a popular destination in its own right amongst both tourists and anglers providing a pleasant walkway across the entire estuary. == Targets and progress == {{see also|EU Renewable Energy Directive 2009/28/EC}} === Targets === {| style="text-align: right" class="wikitable" |+French targets and estimated trajectory of energy from renewable resources in the heating and cooling, electricity and transport sectors. ! !2005 !2008 !2010 !2011 !2012 !2013 !2014 !2015 !2016 !2017 !2018 !2019 !2020 |- | align="left" |RES-H&C |13.6% |14.9% |17.0% |18.0% |19.0% |20.5% |22.0% |24.0% |25.5% |27.5% |29.0% |31.0% |33.0% |- | align="left" |RES-E |13.5% |14.0% |15.5% |16.0% |17.0% |18.0% |19.0% |20.5% |21.5% |23.0% |24.0% |25.5% |27.0% |- | align="left" |RES-T |1.2% |5.6% |6.5% |6.9% |7.2% |7.5% |7.6% |7.7% |8.4% |8.8% |9.4% |10.0% |10.5% |- | align="left" |Overall RES share |9.6% |11.4% |12.5% |13.5% |14.0% |15.0% |16.0% |17.0% |18.0% |19.5% |20.5% |22.0% |23.0% |} Note: Percentage values are shares of renewable energy sources (RES) in the total domestic market for heating and cooling (H&C), electricity (E), and transport (T) sectors. France has an overall target of producing 23% of its total energy needs from renewable energy by 2020, encompassing 33% in the heating and cooling sector, 27% in the electricity sector and 10.5% in the transport sector. === Progress === {| style="text-align: right" class="wikitable" |+Progress in the promotion and use of energy from renewable sources{{Cite web|url = https://ec.europa.eu/energy/en/topics/renewable-energy/progress-reports|title = Report on progress in the promotion and use of energy from renewable sources, 2nd report, Ministry of Ecology, Sustainable Development and Energy|last =|first =|date =|website =|publisher =|access-date =}} ! !2011 !2012 !2013 !2014 |- | align="left" |RES-H&C |15.8% |17.2% |17.8% |17.9% |- | align="left" |RES-E |16.4% |16.7% |16.9% |18.4% |- | align="left" |RES-T |6.9% |7.1% |7.0% |7.6% |- | align="left" |Overall RES share |12.7% |13.7% |14.0% |14.3% |} By 2014 France had achieved a 14.3% renewable energy share of its total energy use, a figure a little below its target figure of 16% by that year. Figures for the transport and electricity sectors were at or near their targets whilst the shortfall in the heating and cooling sector was around 4.1%. This may partially be explained by the ambitious rates targeted for this sector, where other countries typically have higher percentage targets in the electricity sector, a sector that has proven easier to raise the share of renewable energy. == See also == {{Portal|France|Energy|Renewable energy}} * [[Wind power in France]] * [[Solar power in France]] * [[Plug-in electric vehicles in France]] * [[List of renewable energy topics by country|Renewable energy by country]] ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.developpement-durable.gouv.fr/Programmation-pluriannuelle-de-l,48569.html Ministre de l'Environnement, de l'Énergie et de la Mer, Programmation pluriannuelle de l'énergie, 27 October 2016.] * [https://ec.europa.eu/energy/en/topics/renewable-energy/national-action-plans European Commission National Renewable Energy Action Plans] * [https://ec.europa.eu/energy/en/topics/renewable-energy/progress-reports European Commission renewable energy Progress Reports] * [https://ec.europa.eu/energy/en/topics/energy-efficiency/energy-efficiency-directive/national-energy-efficiency-action-plans European Commission National Energy Efficiency Energy Action Plans] {{Renewable energy by country}} [[Category:Renewable energy]]

{{Redirect|Clausius|the lunar crater|Clausius (crater)}} {{Infobox scientist |name = Rudolf Clausius |image = Clausius.jpg |birth_date = {{birth date|1822|1|02|df=yes|}} |birth_place = [[Koszalin|Köslin]], [[Province of Pomerania (1815–1945)|Province of Pomerania]], [[Kingdom of Prussia|Prussia]] (present-day Koszalin, [[Poland]]) |death_date = {{death date and age|1888|08|24|1822|1|02|df=yes|}} |death_place = [[Bonn]], [[Rhine Province]], [[Kingdom of Prussia|Prussia]] |nationality = [[Germany|German]] |ethnicity = |field = [[Physics]] |work_institutions = |alma_mater = |doctoral_advisor = |doctoral_students = |known_for = [[Second law of thermodynamics]]
Originator of the concept of [[entropy]]
[[Clausius-Mossotti relation]]
[[Clausius-Clapeyron relation]]
[[Clausius theorem]]
[[Virial theorem]] |influences = |influenced = |prizes = [[Copley Medal]] (1879) |signature = Rudolf Clausius signature.svg }} '''Rudolf Julius Emanuel Clausius''' ({{IPA-de|ˈʁuːdɔlf ˈklaʊ̯zi̯ʊs}};{{cite book|author1=Dudenredaktion|last2=Kleiner|first2=Stefan|last3=Knöbl|first3=Ralf|year=2015|orig-year=First published 1962|title=Das Aussprachewörterbuch|trans-title=The Pronunciation Dictionary|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=T6vWCgAAQBAJ|language=German|edition=7th|location=Berlin|publisher=Dudenverlag|isbn=978-3-411-04067-4|pp=280, 744}}{{cite book|last1=Krech|first1=Eva-Maria|last2=Stock|first2=Eberhard|last3=Hirschfeld|first3=Ursula|last4=Anders|first4=Lutz Christian|title=Deutsches Aussprachewörterbuch|trans-title=German Pronunciation Dictionary|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=E-1tr_oVkW4C&dq=deutsches+ausspracheworterbuch&source=gbs_navlinks_s|language=German|year=2009|publisher=Walter de Gruyter|location=Berlin|isbn=978-3-11-018202-6|pp=416, 884}} 2 January 1822 – 24 August 1888) was a [[Germany|German]] [[physicist]] and [[mathematician]] and is considered one of the central founders of the science of [[thermodynamics]].{{Citation | author=Cardwell, D.S.L. | title=From Watt to Clausius: The Rise of Thermodynamics in the Early Industrial Age | location=London | publisher=Heinemann | year=1971 | isbn=0-435-54150-1}} By his restatement of [[Nicolas Léonard Sadi Carnot|Sadi Carnot]]'s principle known as the [[Carnot cycle]], he gave the [[theory of heat]] a truer and sounder basis. His most important paper, "On the Moving Force of Heat", published in 1850, first stated the basic ideas of the [[second law of thermodynamics]]. In 1865 he introduced the concept of [[entropy]]. In 1870 he introduced the [[virial theorem]] which applied to [[heat]].{{cite journal | last = Clausius | first = RJE | year = 1870 | title = On a Mechanical Theorem Applicable to Heat | journal = Philosophical Magazine |series=4th Series | volume = 40 | pages = 122–127}} ==Life== Clausius was born in [[Koszalin|Köslin]] (now [[Koszalin]] in Poland) in the [[Province of Pomerania (1815–1945)|Province of Pomerania]] in [[Prussia]]. His father was a [[Protestant]] pastor and school inspector,Emilio Segrè (2012). ''From Falling Bodies to Radio Waves: Classical Physicists and Their Discoveries''. Courier Dover Publications. p. 228 and Rudolf studied in the school of his father. After a few years, he went to the [[Gymnasium (school)|Gymnasium]] in [[Stettin]] (now [[Szczecin]]). Clausius graduated from the [[University of Berlin]] in 1844 where he studied mathematics and physics with, among others, [[Heinrich Gustav Magnus|Gustav Magnus]], [[Peter Gustav Lejeune Dirichlet]] and [[Jakob Steiner]]. He also studied history with [[Leopold von Ranke]]. During 1847, he got his doctorate from the [[University of Halle]] on optical effects in Earth's atmosphere. He then became professor of physics at the Royal Artillery and Engineering School in Berlin and Privatdozent at the Berlin University. In 1855 he became professor at the [[ETH Zürich]], the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology in [[Zürich]], where he stayed until 1867. During that year, he moved to [[University of Würzburg|Würzburg]] and two years later, in 1869 to [[University of Bonn|Bonn]]. In 1870 Clausius organized an ambulance corps in the [[Franco-Prussian War]]. He was wounded in battle, leaving him with a lasting disability. He was awarded the [[Iron Cross]] for his services. His wife, Adelheid Rimpham, died in childbirth in 1875, leaving him to raise their six children. He continued to teach, but had less time for research thereafter. In 1886, he married Sophie Sack, and then had another child. Two years later, on 24 August 1888, he died in [[Bonn]], Germany.{{cite book|first=William H.|last=Cropper|title=Great Physicists: The Life and Times of Leading Physicists from Galileo to Hawking|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UqbxZpELwHYC&pg=PA93|accessdate=25 March 2014|year=2004|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-517324-6|pages=93–105|chapter=The Road to Entropy Rudolf Clausius}} ==Work== Clausius's PhD thesis concerning the refraction of light proposed that we see a blue sky during the day, and various shades of red at sunrise and sunset (among other phenomena) due to reflection and refraction of light. Later, [[Lord Rayleigh]] would show that it was in fact due to the scattering of light, but regardless, Clausius used a far more mathematical approach than some have used. His most famous paper, ''Ueber die bewegende Kraft der Wärme'' ("On the Moving Force of Heat and the Laws of Heat which may be Deduced Therefrom"){{cite journal | last=Clausius |first=R. | title =Ueber die bewegende Kraft der Wärme und die Gesetze, welche sich daraus für die Wärmelehre selbst ableiten lassen |url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k15164w/f518.table | journal =Annalen der Physik | volume =79 | pages=368–397, 500–524| year =1850 | doi=10.1002/andp.18501550403|bibcode = 1850AnP...155..500C }}. See English Translation: [https://archive.org/details/londonedinburghd02lond On the Moving Force of Heat, and the Laws regarding the Nature of Heat itself which are deducible therefrom]. Phil. Mag. (1851), series 4, '''2''', 1–21, 102–119. Also available on [https://books.google.com/books?id=JbwdWbbM1KgC&pg=RA1-PA1#v=onepage&q&f=false Google Books]. was published in 1850, and dealt with the mechanical theory of heat. In this paper, he showed that there was a contradiction between [[Nicolas Léonard Sadi Carnot|Carnot]]'s principle and the concept of [[conservation of energy]]. Clausius restated the two [[laws of thermodynamics]] to overcome this contradiction (the [[third law of thermodynamics|third law]] was developed by [[Walther Nernst]], during the years 1906–1912). This paper made him famous among scientists. Clausius' most famous statement of thermodynamics second law was published in German in 1854,{{cite journal|last=Clausius|first=R.|title=Ueber eine veränderte Form des zweiten Hauptsatzes der mechanischen Wärmetheoriein|journal=[[Annalen der Physik|Annalen der Physik und Chemie]]|year=1854|volume=93|issue=12|pages=481–506|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k15178k/f499.image|accessdate=25 June 2012}} and in English in 1856.{{cite journal|last=Clausius|first=R.|title=On a Modified Form of the Second Fundamental Theorem in the Mechanical Theory of Heat|journal=[[Philosophical Magazine|Phil. Mag.]]|date=August 1856|volume=12|series=4|issue=77|pages=81–98|url=https://archive.org/stream/londonedinburghd12lond#page/80/mode/2up|accessdate=25 June 2012}} {{quotation | Heat can never pass from a colder to a warmer body without some other change, connected therewith, occurring at the same time.}} During 1857, Clausius contributed to the field of [[kinetic theory of gases|kinetic theory]] after refining [[August Krönig]]'s very simple gas-kinetic model to include translational, rotational and vibrational molecular motions. In this same work he introduced the concept of '[[Mean free path]]' of a particle.{{Citation | author=Clausius, R. | title =Über die Art der Bewegung, die wir Wärme nennen | url =http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k15185v/f371.table | journal =Annalen der Physik | volume =100 | pages =353–379 | year =1857|doi=10.1002/andp.18571760302 |bibcode = 1857AnP...176..353C }}{{Citation | author=Clausius, R. | title =Ueber die Wärmeleitung gasförmiger Körper | url =http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k15200x/f13.table | journal =Annalen der Physik | volume =115 | pages =1–57 | year =1862 |doi=10.1002/andp.18621910102 |bibcode = 1862AnP...191....1C }}Clausius, R. (1864), [http://gallica.bnf.fr/notice?N=FRBNF37278069 ''Abhandlungen über die Mechanische Wärmetheorie'']. Electronic manuscript from the [[Bibliothèque nationale de France]]. Clausius deduced the [[Clausius–Clapeyron relation]] from thermodynamics. This relation, which is a way of characterizing the [[phase transition]] between two states of matter such as [[solid]] and [[liquid]], had originally been developed in 1834 by [[Émile Clapeyron]]. ===Entropy=== {{Main|History of entropy}} In 1865, Clausius gave the first mathematical version of the concept of [[entropy]], and also gave it its name. Clausius chose the word because the meaning (from [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] ἐν ''en'' "in" and τροπή ''tropē'' "transformation") is "''content transformative''" or "''transformation content''" ("''Verwandlungsinhalt''").{{cite book|last=Clausius|first=R.|title=The Mechanical Theory of Heat – with its Applications to the Steam Engine and to Physical Properties of Bodies|year=1867|publisher=John van Voorst|location=London|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8LIEAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=editions:PwR_Sbkwa8IC&hl=en&sa=X&ei=h6DgT5WnF46e8gSVvbynDQ&ved=0CDYQuwUwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=19 June 2012}} Contains English translations of many of his other works.{{Citation | author=Clausius, R. | title =Ueber verschiedene für die Anwendung bequeme Formen der Hauptgleichungen der mechanischen Wärmetheorie | url =http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k152107/f369.table | journal =Annalen der Physik | volume =125 | pages =353–400 | year =1865 |doi=10.1002/andp.18652010702|bibcode = 1865AnP...201..353C }} He used the now abandoned unit 'Clausius' (symbol: '''Cl''') for entropy. :1 Clausius (Cl) = 1 [[calorie]]/[[degree Celsius]] (cal/°C) = 4.1868 [[joule]]s per [[kelvin]] (J/K) The landmark 1865 paper in which he introduced the concept of entropy ends with the following summary of the first and second laws of thermodynamics: {{quotation | ''The [[energy]] of the [[universe]] is constant.''
''The [[entropy]] of the universe tends to a maximum.}}'' ==Tributes== [[File:Prawa termodynamiki clausiusa pk.jpg|thumbnail|Memorial stone in front of [[Koszalin University of Technology]], with the laws of thermodynamics as formulated by Clausius]] * Honorary Membership of the [[Institution of Engineers and Shipbuilders in Scotland]] in 1859.[http://www.iesis.org/honorary-fellows.html] * [[Iron Cross]] of 1870 * Fellow of the [[Royal Society of London]] in 1868 and received its [[Copley Medal]] in 1879. * Member of the [[Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences]] in 1878. * [[Huygens]] Medal in 1870. * Foreign Member of the [[Accademia Nazionale dei Lincei]] in Rome in 1880 * Member of the [[German Academy of Sciences Leopoldina]] in 1880 * [[Poncelet Prize]] in 1883. * Honorary doctorate from the [[University of Würzburg]] in 1882. * Foreign Member of the [[Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences]] in 1886.{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.dwc.knaw.nl/biografie/pmknaw/?pagetype=authorDetail&aId=PE00004619 |title=R.J.E. Clausius (1822 - 1888) |publisher=Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences |date= |accessdate=21 July 2015}} * [[Pour le Mérite for Arts and Sciences]] in 1888 * The lunar crater [[Clausius (crater)|Clausius]] named in his honor. * A memorial in his home town of [[Koszalin]] in 2009 ==Publications== * {{cite book|last=Clausius|first=R.|title=The Mechanical Theory of Heat – with its Applications to the Steam Engine and to Physical Properties of Bodies|year=1867|publisher=John van Voorst|location=London|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8LIEAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=editions:PwR_Sbkwa8IC&hl=en&sa=X&ei=h6DgT5WnF46e8gSVvbynDQ&ved=0CDYQuwUwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false}} English translations of nine papers. ==See also== *[[Hans Peter Jørgen Julius Thomsen]], one of the founders of the [[thermochemistry]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{wikiquote}} Rudolf Julius Emmanuel}} * {{Gutenberg author | id=Clausius,+Rudolf | name=Rudolf Clausius}} * {{Internet Archive author |sname=Rudolf Clausius}} {{Copley Medallists 1851-1900}} {{Authority control}} revision.text:
The '''Steppe Geoglyphs''' are a number of earth constructions in the [[Turgai Trough]] area of Turgai in northern [[Kazakhstan]]. There are at least 260 of these [[Earthworks (archaeology)|earthworks]].<ref name=Blumnethal>{{cite news |last=Blumenthal |first=Ralph |date=October 30, 2015 |title=NASA Adds to Evidence of Mysterious Ancient Earthworks |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/03/science/nasa-adds-to-evidence-of-mysterious-ancient-earthworks.html |subscription=yes |accessdate=November 1, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Epstein |first=Adam |date=October 31, 2015 |title=Even NASA is perplexed by these otherworldly 8,000-year-old formations in Kazakhstan |url=http://qz.com/537812/even-nasa-is-perplexed-by-these-otherworldly-8000-year-old-formations-in-kazakhstan/ |accessdate=November 1, 2015 |quote=Since then, Dey has found about 260 of the land designs—which resemble crop circles, but are much stranger.}}</ref>
==The constructions== Many or all of them consist of smaller earthworks (mounds, trenches, and ramparts) arranged with each other to make geometric and other shapes (composite figures). These shapes are squares, rings, and three others.<ref name=Blumnethal/> The composite figures range from slightly under 90 m in length to over 400 m in diameter.<ref>[http://www.pitt.edu/~super1/lecture/lec53991/htm] {{dead link|date=November 2015}}</ref> Besides being made of earth dug out and piled up, some of the geoglyphs are made by placing stones next to each other.<ref>{{cite web |last=Zolfagharifard |first=Ellie |date=October 30, 2015 |title=Who drew a swastika on the steppe 8,000 years ago? NASA images reveal riddle of giant drawings that can only be seen from the air |website=dailymail.co.uk |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-3297282/Mystery-ancient-patterns-Kazakhstan-Space-images-reveal-remarkable-structures-including-cross-swastika.html |accessdate=November 1, 2015}}</ref>
Some of the large shapes have been given names, including Bestamskoe Ring, Ushtogaysky (''or'' Ushtogay) Square, [[Turgay triradial swastika]],<ref>{{cite web |last=Jarus |first=Owen |date=September 23, 2014 |title=Nazca Lines of Kazakhstan: More Than 50 Geoglyphs Discovered |work= |url=http://www.livescience.com/47954-geoglyphs-discovered-in-kazakhstan.html |accessdate=November 1, 2015 |quote=More than 50 geoglyphs with various shapes and sizes, including a massive swastika, have been discovered across northern Kazakhstan in Central Asia, say archaeologists.}}</ref> Large cross Ashtasti, Ekedyn cross, Ashutasti ring, Kyzyloba line, Koga cross, and Shili square.<ref name=Blumnethal/><ref name=Dey>{{cite web|title=Geoglyph Turgay Trough|url=http://www.pitt.edu/~super1/lecture/lec53991/007.htm|website=turgay.kz|publisher=University of Pittsburgh|accessdate=9 November 2015|date=September 2015}}</ref>
These shapes are large enough to be easily visible on Google Earth. The Ushtogay Square is at {{Coord|50.832933|N|65.326276|E|type:landmark|display=inline}}. The Turgay triradial is at {{Coord|50.102778|N|65.360833|E|type:landmark|display=inline}}, only about {{convert|800|m|mi|frac=2}} from the town of [[Urpek]]. Both are inside [[Amangeldi District]], [[Kostanay Region]].
==Discovery and suggested origins== The earthworks were discovered in 2007 by Dimitriy Dey.<ref name=Blumnethal_a>{{cite news |last=Blumnethal |first=Ralph |date=October 30, 2015 |title=NASA Adds to Evidence of Mysterious Ancient Earthworks |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/03/science/nasa-adds-to-evidence-of-mysterious-ancient-earthworks.html |subscription=yes |accessdate=November 1, 2015 |quote=Spotted on Google Earth in 2007 by a Kazakh economist and archaeology enthusiast, Dmitriy Dey, the so-called Steppe Geoglyphs remain deeply puzzling and largely unknown to the outside world.}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Jarus |first=Owen |date=September 23, 2014 |title=Nazca Lines of Kazakhstan: More Than 50 Geoglyphs Discovered |url=http://www.livescience.com/47954-geoglyphs-discovered-in-kazakhstan.html |accessdate=November 1, 2015 |quote=Discovered using Google Earth, the geoglyphs are designed...}}</ref> He found them by searching [[Google Earth]]'s satellite images for pyramids and similar configurations in Kazakhstan.<ref name="Blumnethal_a"/> They were first reported to the scientific community in 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.academia.edu/8610704/Steppe_Geoglyphs_mark_the_ancient_routes_of_human_migration_across_Central_Asia_introduction_to_the_research |title=Steppe Geoglyphs mark the ancient routes of human migration across Central Asia introduction to the research | Irina Shevnina |publisher=Academia.edu |date=1970-01-01 |accessdate=2016-02-16}}</ref>
Optical dating ([[optically stimulated luminescence]]) has been used to determine that one of the mounds dates to around 800 B.C.<ref name=Blumnethal/><ref>[http://www.pitt.edu/~super1/lecture/lec53991/07-018.htm] {{dead link|date=November 2015}}</ref> Dey has proposed they were produced by the [[Mahandzhar culture]] between seven and nine thousand years ago.<ref>{{cite news |author= |date=October 30, 2015 |title=NASA releases images of enormous 8,000-year-old patterns |url=https://www.rt.com/usa/320195-nasa-releases-images-of-enormous/ |accessdate=November 1, 2015 |quote=Dey's research suggests that the figures could have been constructed by the Mahandzhar culture, who thrived in the vast steppes of what is now northern Kazakhstan between 5,000 and 7,000 B.C.}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://discovery.turgay.kz/ Turgay Discovery Research project] * [https://opendrive.gsfc.nasa.gov/shortauth/w/c1wD7oC NASA photographs from space] * [http://www.jqjacobs.net/kml/kazakhstan.kml Kazakhstan Earthworks] KML placemarks file for Google Earth. * {{Coord|50.101705|65.370420|name=Turgay|notes=. Turgay triradial swastika}}

revision.text:
[[Image:Timber slide 1901.jpg|thumb|230px|right|Timber slide in Ottawa, with the Duke of York on timber raft, Sept. 1901.]]
A '''timber slide''' is a device for moving [[timber]] past [[rapids]] and [[waterfall]]s. Their use in [[Canada]] was widespread in the 18th and 19th century [[timber trade]]. At this time, cut timber would be floated down [[river]]s in large [[timber raft]]s from logging camps to ports such as [[Montreal]] and [[Saint John, New Brunswick]]. Rapids and waterfalls would, however, damage the wood and could potentially cause log jams. Thus at these locations timber slides were constructed. These were thin water filled [[chute (gravity)|chutes]] that would run [[Parallel (geometry)|parallel]] to the river. They would usually only be wide enough for a single log and one at a time the logs would be directed down it. The idea is attributed to [[Ruggles Wright]] who introduced the first one in 1829 not far from what is today down-town [[Hull, Quebec]], Canada.<ref>[http://www.timberplus.co.uk/timber-slides/ History of Timber Slides]</ref> Later, the slides could often be up to a kilometre in length. They were most commonly found on the [[Ottawa River]] system.
In some areas the timber slide became a tourist attraction, the most notable being the 1.2 km chute bypassing the [[Chaudière Falls]] on the Ottawa River in [[Ottawa]]. Its most notable visitors are the [[Duke of York]], who later became King [[George V]], and his wife, the [[Duchess of York]] [[Mary of Teck]].<ref>http://niche-canada.org/2016/08/15/sliding-down-the-timber-chute-the-1901-royal-tour-of-canada/</ref>
Timber slides disappeared after the construction of canal networks and the decline of the timber trade. They were almost all out of service by the [[World War I|First World War]].
==See also== * [[Log flume]] * [[Ottawa River timber trade]] * [[//no.wikipedia.org/wiki/T%C3%B8mmerrenne Tømmerrenna]] is the term for a timber slide in Norway where they were also common.
== References == {{reflist}}
* Lee, David. "Lumber Kings and Shantymen: Logging, Lumber and Timber in the Ottawa Valley." Ottawa: Canada, 2006.
[[Category:Wood]] [[Category:Water transport]] [[Category:Log transport]] [[Category:Forestry in Canada]] [[Category:History of forestry]]
